titleStmt.title: A declaration made by the right Honourable the Earle of Bath, one of his Majesties commissioners of array, to the whole country of Devonshire, with their answer thereunto annexed; also the manner how the said Earle of Bath endeavoured to put the commission of array in execution, at South-moulton in Devonshire, and how his men were driven out of the town by the inhabitants thereof. Whereunto is added, a true relation of the great battle betweene Prince Robert and the Parliaments forces at Worcester; with their happy victory over his cavaliers.
titleStmt.author: Bath, Henry Bourchier, Earl of, 1587 or 8-1654.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DECLARATION MADE By the right Honourable the Earle of BATH, one of his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners of Array, to the whole Country of DEVONSHIRE, With their an≈øwer thereunto annexed;

ALSO The manner how the ≈øaid Earle of BATH endeavoured to put the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array in Execution, at Southmoulton in Devon≈øhire, and how his men were driven out of the Town by the Inhabitants thereof.
Whereunto is added, A true Relation of the great Battle betweene Prince ROBERT and the Parliaments Forces at Worce≈øter; with their happy Victory over his Cavaliers.
Septemb. 29. London Printed for John Wright.

div.head: A DECLARATION Of the Earle of BATH.
div.p: AS there are di≈øturbances in ≈øome part of this Kingdome, ≈øo I under≈øtand this County of Devon, in many places to be fal≈øly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of ≈øome arbitrary and Tirannicall government pretended to be ≈øet up by the King, and put in practice (among others by my ≈øelfe) Wherefore out of my great affection to you and my Country, being now immediately ready to receive the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament, I doe ≈øolemnly in the pre≈øence of Almighty God profe≈ø≈øe and declare that I have undertaken nothing contrary to the Lawes of this Kingdome, nor preiudiciall or hurtfull to any that ≈øhall ob≈øerve it: and „Äà‚óä„Äâ doe further profe≈ø≈øe that I have no authority neither will I take the value of ≈øixpence from any man, but to my utmo≈øt power to protect you all, that every one may enioy their owne.

div.head: The An≈øwer.
div.p: THe di≈øturbances that are in this Kingdome have growne through the interferring of the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array with the Militia ordained by Parliament.

The Officers in the Militia are the ≈øame for the mo≈øt part that were before in the Lievtenancy, the men approved by His Maje≈øty; the Array invades the Militia,
and hath beene the onely meanes of breaking the peace. So in Sommer≈øet Captaine Pre≈øton was a≈ø≈øayled and his En≈øigne ≈ølaine in the execution of the ordinance of Parliament. And for that cau≈øe the authors and fautors of that crime are pro≈øecuted in Sherbourne.

That many places of this County are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with the doubt of an arbitrary government intended is true, That the fault therof is layd to the Kings charge is fal≈øe, That the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Array doe for the extent of that Commi≈ø≈øion put in practice an arbitrary and Tirannicall government is true for the≈øe rea≈øons.

Fir≈øt that which is but again≈øt the being of Parliaments is intended for an arbitrary government, but the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Array doe bend them≈øelves and the power of their Commi≈ø≈øions again≈øt the being of Parliaments.
That the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of this Parliament, or the drawing of the members of it to other judicature, is again≈øt the being of Parliaments, is ≈øo apparant as it needs no more proofe.

Secondly That the Commi≈ø≈øion it ≈øelfe is illegall hath beene declared by an authority not to be contradicted. And to put an illegall Commi≈ø≈øion in execution as to draw his Maje≈øties government into the cen≈øure of Tyranny,

Thirdly the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array is mo≈øt partiall and in that re≈øpect Tyrannicall. By the Declaration ju≈øtifying and explaining it, it is affirmed that a man of able body and e≈øtate ≈øerving in per≈øon ≈øhall find armes but for his per≈øon, but a man weake in body not ≈øerving ≈øhal find arms according to the proportion of his e≈øtate, ≈øo that by this rule a man of 40 li. per. an. and impotent ≈øhall find a mans arms & a man to weare it; and a potent man of 100. 500. or 1000. per. an. ≈øhal find no more. A
man that is potent in boby owes that ability to the Common-Wealth as the rich of his ≈øub≈øtance, why el≈øe is the poore able man bound to weare the impotent rich mans armes? It is mo≈øt unrea≈øonable then and con≈øequently mo≈øt illegall, that the bodily ≈øtrength of a rich man which is his great advantage ≈øhould be the rea≈øon to ea≈øe his e≈øtate, and the weakene≈ø≈øe of his equall draw upon him a gro≈ø≈øe inequallity of burthen.

This Declaration averreth peremptorily, that this Commi≈ø≈øion (which is the thing undertaken) is lawfull, that it is not prejudiciall, that there is no authority to take ≈øixpence, and thereupon the holy Sacrament is ≈øolemnly received.
For the lawfulne≈ø≈øe a ≈øingle Iudgment is oppo≈øed to the Parliament and the con≈øcience bound without re≈øervation as ≈øurely for the truth of it.
That's much in re≈øpect of the antiquity oft his law, the variety of others ≈øince made the difference of opinion. But that it is not prejudiciall, let the before recited partiallity an≈øwer.
And for the authority to take ≈øixpence ≈øee the power to impri≈øon the refu≈øers.
With the will of any man Charity forbids to have to doe, becau≈øe his purpo≈øes are hid.
But the con≈øequences of their actions are apparant to provident men.
The Array doth apparently oppo≈øe the Parliament, and intrudes uppon tho≈øe offices which have beene and are now po≈ø≈øe≈øt by others for the peace and defence of the Kingdome.
The Militia defends the Parliament, and therein ≈øtrives to maintaine the King and his po≈øterity in the ancient and rightfull government of this Realme by 3 e≈øtates.
In this there is true loyalty and con≈øtant peace.
In the other flattery and the ≈øeed of perpetuall War.
The Militia protects Religion and propriety of goods, and for the Common intere≈øt in both craves the benefit or Parliament and Church a≈ø≈øemblyes.

The Array prevaling will not faile to bring both into ≈øingle power at lea≈øt into the danger that both were lately in. But that's forgotten, neither is it ≈øeene that the Array mu≈øt embroyle this Kingdome, that the rebellion may prevaile in Ireland.

div.head: A Copy of Letter ≈øent to a worthy Gentleman in LONDON.
div.p: ACcording to my bo ‚Ä¢ nden duty I cannot chu≈øe but acquaint your wor≈øhip with the newes at Southmoulton, I my ≈øelfe being pre≈øent at it.

On Saturday la≈øt, the Earl of Bath ≈øent one of his ≈øervants unto the Maior of the Towne to know whether he ≈øhould have a peaceable entrance into his Town the Tue≈øday folloing, for he was minded to come there, to meet ≈øome Gentlemen upon ≈øome occa≈øions; the Maior an≈øwered the me≈ø≈øenger, that if his intent were for peace, he ≈øhould come, after better con≈øideration, which the Ma
‚Ä¢ or had, he was blamed by ≈øome of his friends, for tha ‚Ä¢ he had not taken re≈øpite to give his an≈øwer, but that advice came too late.

The Tue≈øday being the day appoynted, there came the Eatle of Bath, my Lord Chiche≈øter, Baronet Pollard, Sir Popham Southcot, Sir Ralph Sidneham, Ma≈øter Ba≈ø≈øet, Ma≈øter John Acland, Ma≈øter Iohn Gifford, Captaine Newcond with their followers, and diver≈øe others which I cannot name. A Banquet being provided at Henry Hearders hou≈øe the Inne-keeper, where the Earle ≈øent ≈øtore of Veni≈øon,
and his owne Cooke for to dre≈ø≈øe it, the common ≈øort of the Towne fell in a great rage with the Maior and his company, for giving licence that they ≈øhould enter, and ≈øwor that if they did attempt any thing there, or read their Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, they would beate them all downe and kill them, if they were all hanged for it; and thereupon betooke them≈øelves to Armes, both men, women, and children, about the Cro≈ø≈øe in the Market place, I doe verrily ‚Ä¢ eleeve they were in number at lea≈øt 1000. ≈øome with Musquets loaden, ≈øome with Halberts and blacke Bills, ≈øome with Clubs, ≈øome with Pikes, ≈øome with dunge Evells, ≈øome with great Poles, one I ≈øaw which had heat the calke of a Sive, and beat him out right, and ≈øet him into a long ≈øtaffe, the women had filled all the ≈øteps of the cro≈ø≈øe with great ≈øtones & got up & ≈øate on them, ≈øwearing if they did come there they would braine them. One thing which is worth the noting, a woman which is a Butchers wife, came running with her lapfull of Rams-hornes for to throw at them, ≈øome of the Gentlemen were comming towards the Cro≈ø≈øe, it was thought to publi≈øh the Array, pre≈øently the people gave a ≈øhoute, and did cry, they be come, at which they were all ready to ≈øtand again≈øt them, the Gentlemen ≈øeeing that, betooke them≈øelves every one to hou≈øe, and after that not one of them nor their ≈øervants, dur≈øt ≈øhow them≈øelves in the ≈øtreet; it is thought of many, that if the Towne had not ri≈øen again≈øt them, they would not ≈øo ≈øoone have departed, ≈øurely what≈øoever collor they put upon it, their intent was ill, for their men gave very dangerous ≈øpeeches, but God is able with his ≈ømale≈øt creatures to daunt the hearts of Kings, as with Lice and Frogs and ≈øuch like: ≈øo among≈øt this crew there were both men and women with Clubs and Staves, which doe daily beg from doore to doore, and when the Earl rod forth of Town, they did throw ≈øtones after him and his men. I ≈øhall de≈øire your Wor≈øhips to excu≈øe my boldne≈ø≈øe in writing ≈øo large, but if you had ≈øeene it, you would have thought this Relation to be too little. Thus with my humble ≈øervice unto you and my young Ma≈øter, I commend you both with the whole Family unto the divine protection, and ever re≈øt

div.head: From the Rendevouz in Worce≈øter, Septem. 24. 1642.
div.p:
THe ‚Ä¢ n≈øea≈øonablene≈ø≈øe of the weather in our march with „Äà‚óä„Äâ Artillery, extreamly retarded our comming to Worce≈øter which prevented us of taking the Cavaliers, though not of the City of Worce≈øter, which our Hor≈øe obtained with much Honour though with great difficulty, and di≈øadvantage; for (as I have „Äà‚óä„Äâ from my comrade that was in the fight) Prince Robert with „Äà‚óä„Äâ Troopes came to Worcester, and joyned with Sir Iohn Byron: we had about 10 Troopes neere the City, though not in a body, Prince Robert ≈øallies out of the City, and puts his Hor≈øe in Battal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on the faire Meddow, and ≈øeem ‚Ä¢ d to challenge the Encounter; Colonell Saudis, with his Regiment of Hor≈øe, Captaine Wingate, and Captaine Hales, were about halfe a quarter of a mile, and had n ‚Ä¢ pa≈ø≈øage to the Enemy, but in a lane, where they could not march five a bre≈øt: yet ≈øo keene Colonell Sandis was, that he adventured to march up, and charged the Prince, which he did ≈øo effectually that eleven of them quickly fell, Prince Robert, or Prince Mauri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
being ≈øure wounded in the head, or on his hand: commi≈ø≈øary VVilm t he comes and relieves Prince Robert, and Colonell Sand ‚Ä¢
and he had a ≈øingle encounter, Colonell Sandis received a ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wound, but we hope not mortall, and run his ≈øword up to the hi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in commi≈øary VVilmots body, as it is reported, then Captaine VVingates Troop came on, & did mo≈øt de≈øperate ≈øervice, & after him came Captaine Fines, and Captaine Hale, then came up Captaine Austins Troop, who could not all this while get out of the Lane, and gave a mo≈øt de≈øperate charge, which the enemy being ≈øen≈øible of, aad ≈øeeing more troopes comming, retreated into the City of VVorcester, and Captain Au≈øtin followed them into the City, and did execution on them, and tooke 26 Pri≈øoners, Serieant Maior Dowglas was ≈ølaine on our ≈øide, we lo≈øt no man of note el≈øe, the number ≈ølaine on both ≈øides are much alike, not exceeding thirty on each ≈øide: the Lord Generall is now in the City of VVorce≈øter, and the Maior hath bin twice on his knees to the Lord Generall for his pardon in betraying the City into the hands of the Cavaliers, but cannot obtaine it.
